message_1: A sample of a radioactive substance has an initial mass of 100 grams and a half-life of 5 days. How much of the substance will remain after 20 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 100 grams, the half-life is 5 days, and the time elapsed is 20 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 100 * (1/2)^(20 / 5)

Final mass = 100 * (1/2)^4

Final mass = 100 * (1/16)

Final mass = 100 * 0.0625

Final mass = 6.25 grams

So, after 20 days, 6.25 grams of the radioactive substance will remain.
